newsitem.title: USA: Citicorp share buyback not a big surprise.
newsitem.headline: Citicorp share buyback not a big surprise.

text.p: Citicorp's announcement of an expanded share repurchase program was not a big surprise, analysts said.

The company said it's board of directors on Tuesday authorized the continuation of the existing program to purchase common stock with an additional $4 billion through December 31, 1998, raising to $8.5 billion the total authorized for share buybacks since June 1995.
"My expectations assume that they will continuously be updating these authorizations," said Arthur Soter, analyst at Morgan Stanley & Co.

Citicorp has been telling Wall Street for the last few years that it generates about $2 billion a year in "free capital", which it does not need in its business and this excess capital can be used to repurchase shares.

Asked at the time of the third quarter earnings release in October if buying back shares was a good idea in view of the fact the stock had risen to the mid-90s, executive vice president and principal financial officer Thomas Jones said share buybacks made sense if the market valuation on the company's shares is at a discount relative to other stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500.

Soter said Citicorp has a policy to eliminate excess capital and return it to shareholders and, "the fact of the matter is that with the stock going up, they constantly have to revise these programs."
Citicorp said that, as of September 30, the company had purchased 51.1 million shares under the program for a total outlay of $3.8 billion.
During the third quarter ending September, the company had an average of 485.6 million shares outstanding fully diluted.
Citicorp was up 1-5/8 to 106-7/8 late on Tuesday.
